content: Cu-MFU-4l was prepared according to the literature method with a slight modification. The powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) pattern (Figure S1) indicated that the obtained sample has a similar structure to that of MFU-4l . The inductively coupled plasma–atomic emission spectrometry measurements and potentiometric titration results reveal that the chemical formula was [Cu4ZnCl4(btdd)3] (Figure S2), reflecting that almost all of the tetrahedrally coordinated Zn­(II) ions were replaced by Cu­(II) ions; thus, it can be denoted as Cu 4 II -MFU-4l (). It is worth noting that the content of Cu in our Cu 4 II -MFU-4l sample is higher than that of the previous report, which can be attributed to the longer reaction time in our synthetic procedure. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) of Cu 4 II -MFU-4l revealed a thermal decomposition temperature of 250 °C, suggesting an impressive thermal stability (Figure S3).
clean_text: Cu-MFU-4l  was prepared according to the literature method with a slight modification. The powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) pattern (Figure S1) indicated that the obtained sample has a similar structure to that of MFU-4l . The inductively coupled plasma-atomic emission spectrometry measurements and potentiometric titration results reveal that the chemical formula was [Cu4ZnCl4(btdd)3] (Figure S2), reflecting that almost all of the tetrahedrally coordinated Zn(II) ions were replaced by Cu(II) ions; thus, it can be denoted as Cu 4   II  -MFU-4l  (). It is worth noting that the content of Cu in our Cu 4   II  -MFU-4l  sample is higher than that of the previous report, which can be attributed to the longer reaction time in our synthetic procedure. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) of Cu 4   II  -MFU-4l  revealed a thermal decomposition temperature of 250 °C, suggesting an impressive thermal stability (Figure S3).
